prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: C18O, 13CO, CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
0.3" resolution observations of C18O 3-2 and 13CO 3-2 to measure column density of C18O.
This science goal includes CN, which will trace the photodissociation region at the disk surface (in conjunction with HCN and HNC observations), and a 1.87 GHz wide continuum observation to improve dust disk modeling.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With single-dish observations, we have measured velocity integrated fluxes of 7.9, 2.9, and 8.6 Jy km/s in the 13CO J=3-2, C18O J=3-2, and CN 340.248 GHz line, respectively. All observed lines have FWHM of about 1 km/s and are centered at the stellar velocity of 4.7 km/s LSRK. The ALMA map of integrated CO J=3-2 emission shows emission at the 2 sigma level (1 sigma = 5 mJy/beam km/s) within a 2'' diameter region.
If C18O emission is evenly distributed within this region, the mean integrated flux will be about 80 mJy/beam km/s (for a 0.3'' circular beam) in the J=3-2 line. If C18O emission follows a similar distribution to the CO J=3-2 emission seen with the SMA and with ALMA, we expect emission of about 20 mJy/beam km/s in the J=3-2 line at a distance of 1.5'' from the star, corresponding to the edge of observed emission.
Therefore, for line images with a spectral resolution of 1 km/s, we request a 1 sigma sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam km/s in C18O J=3-2. This will achieve signal-to-noise of at least 4 in the outer edge of emission and S/N ~20 at the spatial peak of emission. According to the ALMA Observing Tool for Cycle 2, our target sensitivity can be achieved with 34 minutes on-source in 4th octile PWV and 16 minutes on source in 2nd octile PWV, respectively. Including calibration and overheads, the total time required for this part of the program is 58 minutes.
The observed CN and C13O emission are both stronger than C18O, so these settings will be sufficient for mapping them, as well.
These proposed observations also include a 1.87 GHz bandwidth correlator settings to map the disk at 341.5 GHz. This will generate a continuum map with a sensitivity of 0.12 mJy/beam, sufficient to measure masses of mm-size dust as low as ~3 x 10^-4 Mjup/beam at the 3 sigma level (e.g. Hildebrand 1983). These much higher sensitivity observations, with a resolution improvement of a factor of 2 relative to our SMA observations, will allow for more meaningful constraints to be made upon the sparse inner disk dust region.
330 GHz observations at uv-distances up to 800 kl will provide excellent uv-coverage even with 15 minute integrations. J1604-2130 passes near zenith for ALMA, therefore observations near transit will have a nearly circular beam that preserves source features without elongation. The circular 0.3'' beam is less than half the size of the best equivalent observation with SMA, is a 50% improvement on Cycle 0 observations, and is well matched to the size scale of several known features of this disk - 880 um emission is seen from 70 AU to at least 140 AU (an inner diameter of ~1'' and outer diameter of ~2''), and the SED requires a small quantity of dust near 20 AU (a diameter of ~0.3''). The disk size is about half the maximum recoverable scale for these observations (~6''), and a CO J=3-2 map of the region made using JCMT HARP shows no extended emission on 7'' scales.
Due to the nearly face-on orientation of the disk, our analysis will focus on images binned to 1 km/s resolution. However, we request correlator setups in the line regions with 61 kHz sampling in order to ensure sufficient spectral resolution to identify lines. We split one of our sidebands to carry out a serindipitous search for SO.
For our continuum region centered at 341.5 GHz, we request bandwidth of 1.87 GHz, with a sampling of 976.6 kHz. All correlator setups use Hanning smoothing.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCO+, H13CO+, DCO+, and CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
0.3" resolution observations of HCO+, H13CO+, and DCO+. These constrain the disk ionization fraction (a key parameter for interpreting the disk chemistry). Furthermore, if detected, DCO+ serves as a tracer of the midplane CO snowline, providing a key constraint on the overall disk temperature model
This science goal also includes CO 3-2 to measure the temperature along the upper surface of the disk region with gas-phase CO. This will provide an important constraint on modeling the overall disk structure, a necessary tool for the interpretation of all other lines.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With single-dish observations, we have measured a velocity integrated flux of 4.3 Jy km/s in the HCO+ J=4-3 line. It has a FWHM of about 1 km/s and is centered at the stellar velocity of 4.7 km/s LSRK.
If HCO+ emission is evenly distributed within the same region as CO, the mean integrated flux will be about 120 mJy/beam km/s (for a 0.3'' circular beam). If HCO+ emission follows a similar distribution to the CO J=3-2 emission seen with the SMA and with ALMA, we expect emission of about 30 mJy/beam km/s at a distance of 1.5'' from the star, corresponding to the edge of observed emission.
Therefore, for line images with a spectral resolution of 1 km/s, we request a 1 sigma sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam km/s in HCO+ J=4-3. This will achieve signal-to-noise of at least 6 in the outer edge of emission and S/N ~30 at the spatial peak of emission. According to the ALMA Observing Tool for Cycle 2, our target sensitivity can be achieved with 21 minutes on-source in 4th octile PWV and 12 minutes on source in 2nd octile PWV, respectively. Including calibration and overheads, the total time required for this part of the program is 49 minutes.
The observed CO emission is much stronger than HCO+, so these settings will be sufficient for mapping them, as well. The H13CO+ and DCO+ intensities are unknown, but will be detectable at abundances corresponding to tau ~0.1.
350 GHz observations at uv-distances up to 800 kl will provide excellent uv-coverage even with 15 minute integrations. J1604-2130 passes near zenith for ALMA, therefore observations near transit will have a nearly circular beam that preserves source features without elongation. The circular 0.3'' beam is less than half the size of the best equivalent observation with SMA, is a 50% improvement on Cycle 0 observations, and is well matched to the size scale of several known features of this disk - 880 um emission is seen from 70 AU to at least 140 AU (an inner diameter of ~1'' and outer diameter of ~2''), and the SED requires a small quantity of dust near 20 AU (a diameter of ~0.3''). The disk size is about half the maximum recoverable scale for these observations (~6''), and a CO J=3-2 map of the region made using JCMT HARP shows no extended emission on 7'' scales.
Due to the nearly face-on orientation of the disk, our analysis will focus on images binned to 1 km/s resolution. However, we request correlator setups in the line regions with 61 kHz sampling in order to ensure sufficient spectral resolution to identify lines. All correlator setups use Hanning smoothing.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2CO, HCN, HNC
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
0.3" resolution observations of H2CO to trace gas desorption at the inner disk edge.
This science goal includes HCN and HNC, which will be used with CN to trace the photodissociation region at the disk surface.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
With single-dish observations, we have measured velocity integrated fluxes of 2.9, 5.1, and 4.6 Jy km/s in the H2CO 351.769 GHz, HCN J=4-3, and HNC J=4-3 lines, respectively. All observed lines have FWHM of about 1 km/s and are centered at the stellar velocity of 4.7 km/s LSRK. The ALMA map of integrated CO J=3-2 emission shows emission at the 2 sigma level (1 sigma = 5 mJy/beam km/s) within a 2'' diameter region.
If H2CO emission is evenly distributed within this region, the mean integrated flux will be about 80 mJy/beam km/s (for a 0.3'' circular beam). If H2CO emission follows a similar distribution to the CO J=3-2 emission seen with the SMA and with ALMA, we expect emission of about 20 mJy/beam km/s at a distance of 1.5'' from the star, corresponding to the edge of observed emission.
Therefore, for line images with a spectral resolution of 1 km/s, we request a 1 sigma sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam km/s in H2CO 5(1,5)-4(1,4). This will achieve signal-to-noise of at least 4 in the outer edge of emission and S/N ~20 at the spatial peak of emission. According to the ALMA Observing Tool for Cycle 2, our target sensitivity can be achieved with 19 minutes on-source in 4th octile PWV and 11 minutes on source in 2nd octile PWV, respectively. Including calibration and overheads, the total time required for this part of the program is 44 minutes.
The observed HCN and HNC emission are both stronger than H2CO, so these settings will be sufficient for mapping them, as well.
These proposed observations also include a 1.87 GHz bandwidth correlator setting to map the disk at 365.58 GHz. This will generate a continuum map witha sensitivity of 0.12 mJy/beam, sufficient to measure masses of mm-size dust as low as ~3 x 10^-4 Mjup/beam at the 3 sigma level (e.g. Hildebrand 1983). These much higher sensitivity observations, with a resolution improvement of a factor of 2 relative to our SMA observations, will allow for more meaningful constraints to be made upon the sparse inner disk dust region.
360 GHz observations at uv-distances up to 800 kl will provide excellent uv-coverage even with 15 minute integrations. J1604-2130 passes near zenith for ALMA, therefore observations near transit will have a nearly circular beam that preserves source features without elongation. The circular 0.3'' beam is less than half the size of the best equivalent observation with SMA, is a 50% improvement on Cycle 0 observations, and is well matched to the size scale of several known features of this disk - 880 um emission is seen from 70 AU to at least 140 AU (an inner diameter of ~1'' and outer diameter of ~2''), and the SED requires a small quantity of dust near 20 AU (a diameter of ~0.3''). The disk size is about half the maximum recoverable scale for these observations (~6''), and a CO J=3-2 map of the region made using JCMT HARP shows no extended emission on 7'' scales.
Due to the nearly face-on orientation of the disk, our analysis will focus on images binned to 1 km/s resolution. However, we request correlator setups in the line regions with 61 kHz sampling in order to ensure sufficient spectral resolution to identify lines. We split our basebands in order to search for SO2, H213CO2, and additional transitions of H2CO.
For our continuum region centered at 365.58 GHz, we request bandwidth of 1.87 GHz, with a sampling of 976.6 kHz. All correlator setups use Hanning smoothing.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose 0.3'' resolution band 7 line imaging of [PZ99] J160421.7-213028. Recent imaging shows this star hosts a transitional disk with a 70 AU radius inner hole (~1'' diameter). This is one of the largest inner holes known from mm-interferometry and a complex inner disk dust structure suggests the presence of giant planets. It is also one of the most emission-line rich transition disks. As a K star, the relatively low-energy photon environment is conducive to the survival of large molecules to be potentially incorporated in forming planets.
To establish a baseline understanding of the disk chemistry, we seek to map the following single-dish detected species: 1) C18O and 13CO J=3-2 to constrain the gas surface density function (essential for modeling the overall disk structure), 2) resolved imaging of CN, HCN, and HNC (which probe the upper disk atmosphere photochemistry), 3) H2CO (expected to trace grain desorption at the inner disk edge), and 4) HCO+ (to provide a measurement of disk ionization). Together, these observations will provide one of the most complete pictures yet achieved of the chemistry of a transition disk. This program will require 2.5 hours.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00471.S, "The site of disk evolution: mapping the inner disk edge of J1604-2130", Geoffrey Mathews
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
